ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Improved my critical thinking skills; learned about historiography and how to undertake a historiographical project; broadened the scope of my perspective and research interests beyond musicology
I have developed skills for thinking critically about music history, and I come away with many new insights into the various perplexities that are involved in writing about historical events.
This course gave me a very thorough grounding in european theories and philosophies of history from midcentury to around 2000.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class was quite intense...Overall, I think the intensity could be toned down at times about 1015% without any real consequence. But we learned many things that are applicable to how we approach scholarship, within and outside of music. It's very clear why it's a staple of the curriculum.
Strengths include a good balance between breadth of topics and depth of engagement. I always came away from class meetings with a richer understanding of the material.

I appreciated that we read many texts outside the musical field. I appreciated the challenge of the ideas and topics of the course. The reading list was thorough though at times too demanding. I would skip the Taruskin or do a shorter excerpt.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, though I would give them fair warning.
